title: Grade 11 English Language Arts
teaser: Students delve deeply into works by acclaimed authors and historical figures.

children.title: How do authors develop and relate elements of a text?
children.teaser: Students read, discuss, and analyze literary and nonfiction texts.

children.title: Then All Smiles Stopped Together
children.teaser: Students engage in critical analysis of texts to explore deep meanings.

children.title: Impact of word choice on meaning and tone
children.teaser: Students analyze the impact of specific words on meaning, citing evidence to support their analysis.

children.title: Annotation and Discussion
children.teaser: Students continue studying Browning’s poem, building close reading skills, and practicing text annotation.

children.title: The Speaker and Gets the Last Word
children.teaser: Students discuss the impact of Browning’s choice of speaker on the Duchess’s character development.

children.title: Developing Character
children.teaser: Students focus on relevant evidence to write about how Browning continues to develop the Duke.

children.title: Vocabulary, Syntax and Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students examine how Browning develops central ideas, like power and status, control, jealousy, and voice.

children.title: Unit Assessment: Revelation
children.teaser: Students engage in an evidence-based discussion of Browning’s choices about introducing and developing the Duke.

children.title: Tho This Be Madness, Yet There Is Method In't
children.teaser: Students critically analyze texts for deep meaning and collect and analyze evidence for use in writing and discussion.

children.title: Implications of the First Scene
children.teaser: Students explore Shakespeare’s language, initial plot points, characters, and the setting of the play.

children.title: Hamlet and Claudius
children.teaser: Students examine the emergence of concepts, such as gender roles, duty, and mortality.

children.title: Claudius Reveals Himself
children.teaser: They focus to the development of Claudius, following a focus on Hamlet’s character development.

children.title: Hamlet from Two Perspectives
children.teaser: Students consider the impact of Shakespeare’s choice to introduce Hamlet from two perspectives.

children.title: Gertrude through Hamlet's Eyes
children.teaser: Student discuss the meaning of and about how Shakespeare develops the Queen through this soliloquy.

children.title: Laertes and Ophelia:  Gender Roles
children.teaser: Students analyze Laertes’s farewell monologue to Ophelia.  Students are able to engage with crucial concepts.

children.title: Revenge
children.teaser: Students discuss the impact of word choices on the development of central ideas.

children.title: Figurative Language
children.teaser: Students analyze Shakespeare’s figurative language and its contribution to the development of central ideas.

children.title: Staging a Play
children.teaser: Students discuss how these elements—plot, character, order of action—interact to develop the drama.

children.title: Developing Hamlet through Soliloquy
children.teaser: Students write an essay about how Shakespeare develops Hamlet’s character in relation to other characters.

children.title: Engaging Language
children.teaser: Students focus on how Shakespeare’s word choice impacts the meaning of Hamlet’s soliloquy.

children.title: Interaction of Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students shift focus from figurative language to the development of central ideas in the soliloquy.

children.title: Hamlet and Ophelia
children.teaser: Students examine the development of Ophelia’s character in relation to other characters in Act 3.1.

children.title: Laertes and Ophelia
children.teaser: Students focus on the development of Ophelia’s character in relation to Hamlet and Laertes.

children.title: What Ophelia Thinks
children.teaser: Students read Ophelia’s monologue on Hamlet’s madness, writing about her perspective and characterization of Hamlet.

children.title: Claudius Confesses and Hamlet Delays
children.teaser: Students discuss how Shakespeare orders the action and further develops characters through soliloquies.

children.title: Analyzing Monologues
children.teaser: Students read Act 3.4, Hamlet’s murder of Polonius and confrontation with Gertrude, analyzing Hamlet’s words.

children.title: Final Soliloquy
children.teaser: Students examine the development of Hamlet’s character and Fortinbras’s role as a foil for Hamlet.

children.title: Analyzing how Central Ideas Develop through Scenes
children.teaser: Students use annotation to focus on central ideas they encounter in Hamlet’s last soliloquy.

children.title: Impact of Setting
children.teaser: Students focus on how the scene further develops important text elements.

children.title: How Characters Develop In Response to Death
children.teaser: Students analyze how Shakespeare develops his characters through their responses to Ophelia’s death.

children.title: The Poisoned Blade
children.teaser: Students assess how central ideas developed throughout the play interact during the final scene.

children.title: Tragic Resolution
children.teaser: Students analyze how Hamlet’s character is developed in the tragic resolution.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 1: Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students support analysis of how central ideas interact and build upon one another in Hamlet.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 2: How Figurative Language Develops Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students draft a multi-paragraph response to the End-of-Unit Assessment prompt.

children.title: Anonymity Runs In Their Blood
children.teaser: Students engage with Virginia Woolf’s A Room of One’s Own.

children.title: Comprehension and Analysis
children.teaser: Students write an objective summary of the text and determine a central idea.

children.title: Judith Shakespeare
children.teaser: Students must demonstrate how Woolf develops a central idea through language and character comparison.

children.title: Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students examine Woolf’s point of view and use of rhetoric.

children.title: Interactions of Ideas and Events
children.teaser: Woolf writes about the stress of society’s expectations on female writers throughout history.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students complete a response analyzing the development and interaction of two or more central ideas.

children.title: Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students consider the relationship between events and central ideas in the text.

children.title: Revisiting Ophelia
children.teaser: Students review central ideas from Woolf’s text and apply them to an excerpt from Hamlet.

children.title: Unit Assessment:  Woolf and Shakespeare
children.teaser: Students craft a response analyzing the relationship between Woolf’s text and the character of Ophelia.

children.title: Figurative Language and Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students read, discuss, and analyze literary and informational texts.

children.title: Analyzing Use of Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students analyze two seminal texts about African Americans in post-Emancipation America.

children.title: Effect of Epigraph
children.teaser: Students analyze paragraph one and consider the effect created by the author’s choice of epigraph.

children.title: How DuBois Introduces and Develops Key Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how Du Bois introduces ideas, and consider how they interact and develop.

children.title: The Role of Figurative Language
children.teaser: Students analyze Du Bois’s use of figurative language, determining meaning from context.

children.title: Double-Consciousness and True Self-Consciousness
children.teaser: Students examine the ideas that Du Bois develops, including "double-consciousness" and "true self-consciousness".

children.title: How DuBois Develops Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students discuss how to develop a topic through the selection of relevant evidence.

children.title: Impact of Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students use the Rhetorical Impact Tracking Tool to record their analysis.

children.title: Refining Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how Du Bois continues to refine his central idea of double-consciousness.

children.title: Allusions and Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students analyze Du Bois’s use of rhetoric through emotional and religious appeals and allusions.

children.title: Renewed Optimism of 15th Amendment
children.teaser: Student analysis focuses on how Du Bois further shapes and refine previously established ideas.

children.title: The Mountain Path to Canaan
children.teaser: Du Bois introduces the key metaphor of "the mountain path to Canaan".

children.title: Weaving Together Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how Du Bois weaves together and develops ideas introduced earlier in the text.

children.title: Prejudice
children.teaser: Students analyze how Du Bois develops and refines the meaning of prejudice.

children.title: The Power of DuBois' Style and Content
children.teaser: Students consider how style and content contribute to the power and persuasiveness of the text.

children.title: Attaining Liberty
children.teaser: Students examine how central ideas interact and build on one another in this excerpt.

children.title: An Effective Conclusion
children.teaser: Students discuss Du Bois’s purpose for writing and how he refines a central idea.

children.title: Epigraph: The Crying of Water
children.teaser: Students analyze how the poem contributes to the overall meaning of Du Bois’s text.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Central Idea
children.teaser: Students develop coherent responses; select relevant facts; use appropriate transitions to clarify relationships among ideas.

children.title: Establishing a Point of View
children.teaser: Students analyze how Washington establishes his point of view in the opening of his speech.

children.title: Washington's Use of Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students explore Washington’s rhetoric to analyze how his style and content contribute to his persuasiveness.

children.title: Cast Down your Bucket
children.teaser: Students explore how Washington refines the meaning of the phrase "[c]ast down your bucket".

children.title: How Rhetoric Contributes to Power of Text
children.teaser: Students analyze how word choice and rhetoric contributes to the power of his text.

children.title: Precise Language
children.teaser: Students discuss the importance of using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary when writing about complex ideas.

children.title: How Central Ideas Build Upon Each Other
children.teaser: Student analyze development and refinement of central ideas and how these ideas support his purpose.

children.title: Different Authors, Similar Ideas
children.teaser: Students focus on how the respective authors develop related central ideas.

children.title: Central and Supporting Claims
children.teaser: Students identify Washington and Du Bois’s central and supporting claims, analyzing the relationships between them.

children.title: Assessment:  Using Rhetoric to Advance Point of View
children.teaser: Students develop written analyses that convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly.

children.title: I Am The Sun And Moon And Forever Hungry
children.teaser: Students read and analyze two texts that explore issues of agency and identity for women in America.

children.title: Word Choice
children.teaser: Student analysis focuses on how Cady Stanton begins to establish her purpose in this excerpt.

children.title: Satire and Sarcasm
children.teaser: Students analyze how Cady Stanton’s strategic use of satire and sarcasm advances her purpose.

children.title: Organizing Ideas
children.teaser: Focused questioning supports student analysis of Cady Stanton’s organization and development of ideas.

children.title: Rhetorical Impact
children.teaser: Students discuss establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone in their writing.

children.title: Using Figurative Language to Develop Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how Cady Stanton introduces or develops key ideas through figurative language.

children.title: A Strong Conclusion
children.teaser: Students discuss how concluding statements support previously presented information or explanations.

children.title: The Power, Persuasiveness and Beauty of the Text
children.teaser: Student analysis focuses on Cady Stanton’s use of rhetoric and how it advances her purpose.

children.title: Reasoning and Evidence to Support a Central Claim
children.teaser: Students discuss Cady Stanton’s central claim and supporting claims analyzing evidence support these claims.

children.title: Understanding Complex Relationships through Connotation and Figurative Language
children.teaser: Students determine the meanings of words, analyzing how they shape the meaning of the stanza.

children.title: How Relationships Impact Identity
children.teaser: Students interpret the meaning of the figurative language and analyze the role it plays.

children.title: Duality of Identity
children.teaser: Students analyze how Lorde shapes and refines central ideas in her poem.

children.title: Development of Ideas Across Text
children.teaser: Students refine their understanding of the central ideas in Lorde’s poem.

children.title: Assessment: Bringing Ideas Together
children.teaser: Students select texts and the similar central ideas on which to focus their writing.

children.title: Assessment: Analysis of Approaches to Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students compare central ideas from the texts and authors’ approaches to develop them.

children.title: Researching Multiple Perspectives to Develop a Position
children.teaser: Students engage in an inquiry-based, iterative process for research.

children.title: Using a Seed Text as a Springboard to Research
children.teaser: Students closely read Elie Wiesel’s Nobel Lecture, “Hope, Despair and Memory.,”

children.title: The Central Ideas of Memory, Hope and Suffering
children.teaser: Students focus on the language Wiesel uses, identifying how his words evoke images and emotions.

children.title: Specific Language, Imagery, and Paradox
children.teaser: Students analyze how Wiesel uses specific language, imagery, and varied syntax to advance a purpose.

children.title: Language and Rhetoric
children.teaser: Students focus on how Wiesel continues to develop the idea of memory.

children.title: Wiesel: Paradox; Research: Generating Inquiry Questions
children.teaser: Wiesel uses the paradox of the importance of remembering with the capacity to forget.

children.title: Wiesel: Rhetoric; Research: Refining Inquiry Questions
children.teaser: Students continue to surface issues that arise in the text for the purpose of research.

children.title: Weisel: Central Ideas; Research: Tracking Potential Issues
children.teaser: Wiesel references contemporary examples of injustice and steps needed to correct them.

children.title: Wiesel: Claims, Evidence, and Reasoning
children.teaser: Students explore how Wiesel crafts a persuasive and compelling lecture, working to delineate his argument.

children.title: Potential Areas of Investigation
children.teaser: Students collaborate to further develop perspectives and understandings of the variety of topics surfaced.

children.title: Pre-Search: Is My Topic Workable?
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the vocabulary journal as a way of organizing domain-specific language

children.title: Considering Authors' Perspectives in Potential Sources
children.teaser: Students engage in discussion around authors’ perspectives and consider them as they search for sources.

children.title: Assessment:  Central Ideas;Research: Possible Areas of Investigation
children.teaser: Students write about several areas of investigation that have emerged from the reading.

children.title: Research Process
children.teaser: Students begin pursuing problem-based research questions.

children.title: Research Portfolio
children.teaser: Students vet possible areas of investigation and select a research topic.

children.title: Generating More Specific Questions
children.teaser: Students learn how to generate more specific inquiry questions to frame their research.

children.title: Effective and Efficient Research
children.teaser: Students learn how to select inquiry questions to conduct effective and efficient research.

children.title: Annotation
children.teaser: Students learn to read important sources for selected inquiry questions using annotation and note taking.

children.title: Evaluating Evidence-based Arguments
children.teaser: Students learn how to evaluate an evidence-based argument, identifying necessary components of a compelling argument.

children.title: Formal Planning
children.teaser: Students use the Research Frame Tool to guide their research.

children.title: Sustained and Independent Research
children.teaser: Students consider how to use inquiry questions to drive research and assess sources for credibility.

children.title: Sustained and Independent Research: Making Adjustments
children.teaser: Students read sources closely, analyze details, evaluate arguments, and determine how it addresses inquiry questions.

children.title: Final Decisions about Direction
children.teaser: Students assess their current search process and make strategic decisions about changes, additions, and deletions.

children.title: Forming Evidence-Based Claim Tool
children.teaser: Students analyze and synthesize their research to begin making claims about inquiry questions.

children.title: Organization, Analysis, and Synthesis of Claims
children.teaser: Students develop comprehensive claims about each inquiry path in the Research Frame.

children.title: Claims and Counterclaims
children.teaser: Students choose a claim and decide what kind of counterclaim would be most effective.

children.title: Presentation Outline
children.teaser: Students use a Presentation Outline Tool to prepare oral presentations of claims, evidence, and reasoning.

children.title: Presentation of Claims
children.teaser: Students present their research findings in small groups, articulating a perspective on their topic.

children.title: Assessment: Submitting the Portfolio
children.teaser: Students complete write an Evidence-Based Perspective that synthesizes their evidence collection and research work.

children.title: Synthesizing Research and Argument Through the Writing Process
children.teaser: Students engage in the writing process.

children.title: Developing a Research-Based Argument Paper
children.teaser: Students determine a central claim and construct an outline for the research- based argument paper.

children.title: Counterclaims
children.teaser: Students address the strengths and limitations of their central claims by developing support for counterclaims.

children.title: Integrating Information and Works Cited
children.teaser: Students learn how to integrate citation information into their paper and follow a standard format for citation.

children.title: Peer Review and Exemplars
children.teaser: Students then learn about the purpose and components of an effective introduction.

children.title: Effectiveness of Writing:  Transitions and Connecting Ideas
children.teaser: Students focus on the use of transitional words and phrases building strong relationships within their papers.

children.title: Concluding Statements
children.teaser: Students craft a concluding statement that supports the argument and connects sections of the text.

children.title: Formal Style and Objective Tone
children.teaser: Students learn to identify and use formal style and objective tone when writing their papers.

children.title: Revision, Norms and Conventions
children.teaser: Students learn how to incorporate argument norms and conventions into their writing.

children.title: Revising for Flow and Cohesiveness
children.teaser: Students focus on editing for flow and the cohesiveness of the entire research paper.

children.title: Editing for Grammar
children.teaser: Students are introduced to language standards as well as to common hyphenation conventions.

children.title: Constructive Feedback and Writing Conventions
children.teaser: Students offer constructive feedback to their classmates about the entire research-based argument paper.

children.title: Assessment: Polishing and Submitting
children.teaser: Students finalize their research-based argument papers by editing, polishing, and rewriting as necessary.

children.title: Narrative Techniques InFiction Writing
children.teaser: Complex characters who demonstrate conflicts between social conventions and the human psyche.

children.title: Point of View
children.teaser: Students analyze the authors’ uses of structure and point of view.

children.title: It's About One's Point of View
children.teaser: Students begin analysis of “On the Rainy River,” from The Things They Carried.

children.title: Escaping the Draft
children.teaser: Students pay particular attention to the way interrelated elements contribute to plot development.

children.title: How Point of View Develops Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students discuss the conclusion of the text and how point of view develops central ideas.

children.title: Meaning of Text
children.teaser: Students focus on how certain parts of the text contribute to overall meaning and structure.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: How Part Contributes to Whole
children.teaser: Students convey complex ideas accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

children.title: Creating a Narrative
children.teaser: Students write a narrative introduction establishing point of view and creating a progression of experiences.

children.title: Peer Review 2
children.teaser: Students engaged in peer reviews to provide standards for crafting introductions.

children.title: How One's Point of View Impacts Characterization of Another
children.teaser: Students focus on how the narrator’s point of view impacts the character development of others.

children.title: Analysis of Textual Elements
children.teaser: Students complete their reading and analysis of "The Red Convertible", pages 4–10.

children.title: Impact of Aesthetics
children.teaser: Students consider how information about the ending of the story impacts it as a whole.

children.title: Incorporating Narrative Techniques in Writing
children.teaser: Students learn to incorporate narrative techniques into their writing to develop events, experiences, and characters.

children.title: Peer Review
children.teaser: Students engage in peer review and revision of their text-based narrative writing pieces.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 1: Considering Points of View
children.teaser: Students analyze point of view.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 2: Key Scene from Another's Perspective
children.teaser: Students brainstorm and prewrite in preparation for drafting narrative writing pieces.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 2: Peer Review and Revision
children.teaser: Students peer review and revise for engaging introductions and effective use of narrative writing techniques.

children.title: Unit Assessment Part 2: Finalization
children.teaser: Students finalize their narrative writing pieces by editing, polishing, and rewriting as necessary.

children.title: Structural Techniques
children.teaser: Students consider setting, plot, and character in developing related central ideas.

children.title: Who Gets Introduced First
children.teaser: Students focus on the impact of Chopin’s choice to introduce Mr. Pontellier before his wife.

children.title: Phrasing and Social Roles
children.teaser: Students analyze Chopin’s use of figurative language, specifically the term “mother-woman”.

children.title: Use of Language
children.teaser: Students incorporate precise words and phrases and sensory language to provide a picture of experiences.

children.title: Revision and Peer Review
children.teaser: Students revise and peer review of one of their narrative writing pieces.

children.title: Development of Central Ideas: Sense of Self and Societal Expectations
children.teaser: Analysis focuses on development of the central ideas of sense of self and societal expectations.

children.title: Development of Edna
children.teaser: Students analyze the development of Edna’s character in relation to both her husband and Robert.

children.title: Central Ideas and How They Relate
children.teaser: Student analysis focuses on the continued development and interaction of two central ideas.

children.title: Societal Expectations
children.teaser: In this excerpt, Edna and Mr. Pontellier have an argument about societal obligations.

children.title: Edna's Character Development and Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how Edna’s character development contributes to the development of two related central ideas.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment: Character Development and Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze how the development of Edna’s character contributes to two interrelated central ideas.

children.title: Writing: Revisiting the Narrative
children.teaser: Students use various techniques to sequence events so they build toward a particular outcome.

children.title: Peer Review and Revision
children.teaser: Students peer review and revise their drafts for the structural techniques.

children.title: Analyzing Evidence of Central Ideas
children.teaser: Students analyze evidence of how the central ideas interact and build on one another.

children.title: Writing to Prepare for Whole Class Discussion
children.teaser: Students consider Edna’s character development in relation to the development of two interrelated central ideas.

children.title: Story Elements and Characterization
children.teaser: Student analysis focuses on story elements and how related elements contribute to Edna’s character development.

children.title: Writing and Discussion:  Robert's Return and Edna
children.teaser: Students consider in writing and a whole-class discussion how Robert’s return impacts Edna’s character development.

children.title: Critical Dialogue About Central Ideas
children.teaser: Student analysis focuses on how central ideas build on one another and interact.

children.title: Aesthetic Impact
children.teaser: Student analyze the conclusion contributes to the meaning and aesthetic impact of the narrative.

children.title: Analyzing our Written Conclusions
children.teaser: Students analyze the conclusions from the three texts.  They craft conclusions to their narrative writing.

children.title: Peer Review of Text-Based Narratives
children.teaser: Students craft conclusions that reflect upon what is experienced and observed during the narrative.

children.title: Analysis and  Evidence to Support Claim: Assessment Pre-work
children.teaser: Students identify characters or societal expectations responsible for the tragic conclusion of the text.

children.title: Assessment:  Evidence-Based Discussion
children.teaser: Students make a claim about who/what bears the most responsibility for the tragic conclusion.

children.title: Developing Core Proficiencies Curriculum
children.teaser: These units model instruction and provide flexible materials to use and adapt for a variety of contexts.

children.title: Reading Closely for Textual Details
children.teaser: Grades 11-12: "We, as a people, will get to the promised land!"

children.title: Between Man And His God
children.teaser: Students analyze visual-based texts.

children.title: A Violation of the Establishment Clause
children.teaser: Students read and analyze informational texts.

children.title: Plausible Secular Purpose
children.teaser: Students read, analyze, and compare texts.

children.title: The Instruments Of Peace
children.teaser: Students read and analyze three related texts.

children.title: If I Had Sneezed
children.teaser: Students learn the characteristics of an effective text-based discussion.

children.title: Reading Closely for Textual Details (Continued)
children.teaser: Grades 11-12: "And I am willing to lay down all my joys in this life, to help maintain this Government"

children.title: Several Dead Bodies Lie Near
children.teaser: Students analyze visual-based texts.

children.title: Emancipation Is The Demand Of Civilization
children.teaser: Students read and analyze informational texts.

children.title: An Important New Dimension To The Civil War
children.teaser: Students read, analyze, and compare texts.

children.title: Lay Down All My Joys In This Life
children.teaser: Students read and analyze three related texts.

children.title: Civil War Has Only Horror For Me
children.teaser: Students learn the characteristics of an effective text-based discussion.

children.title: Making Evidence-Based Claims
children.teaser: "The Souls of Black Folk," W.E.B Du Bois

children.title: An Unasked Question
children.teaser: Students learn the elements of making evidence-based claims.

children.title: Experiencing Twoness
children.teaser: Students develop the ability to make evidence-based claims.

children.title: Strangely Wasted Talent
children.teaser: Students organize evidence to develop and expand claims.

children.title: Testing the Great Republic
children.teaser: Students express evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: On Our Spiritual Strivings
children.teaser: Students express global evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: Making Evidence-Based Claims about Literary Technique
children.teaser: "The Red Convertible," Louise Erdrich, and "On the Rainy River," Tim O'Brien

children.title: We Owned It Together Until His Boots Filled With Water
children.teaser: Students learn the elements of making evidence-based claims.

children.title: I Still See That Picture Now, As If It Tugs At Me
children.teaser: Students develop the ability to make evidence-based claims.

children.title: My Boots Are Filling
children.teaser: Students organize evidence to develop and expand claims.

children.title: This Is One Story I've Never Told Before.
children.teaser: Students express evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: I Survived, But It's Not A Happy Ending.
children.teaser: Students express global evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: Researching to Deepen Understanding
children.teaser: Grades 11-12: Research Topic Repository - Food and Design

children.title: Initiating Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 1, students will have identified an Area of Investigation and developed Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Gathering Information
children.teaser: By the end of Part 2, students will have assessed the main common sources and gathered notes about the information in the texts.

children.title: Deepening Understanding
children.teaser: By the end of Part 3, students will have a series of evidence-based claims addressing their Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Finalizing Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 4, students will have an analyzed body of research addressing their Inquiry Questions from which to develop and communicate an evidence- based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Developing And Communicating An Evidence-Based Perspective
children.teaser: By the end of Part 5, students will have an organized body of research and have written an evidence-based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Building Evidence-Based Arguments
children.teaser: “Culpae poena par esto: Let the punishment fit the crime.”

children.title: An incarceration rate that is many times higher than that of comparable countries is a signal that something is very wrong.
children.teaser: Students understand an issue as a context for various perspectives, positions, and arguments.

children.title: The prison has become a looming presence in our society to an extentunparalleled in our history--or that of any other industrial democracy.
children.teaser: Students analyze the position, evidence, and perspective of arguments.

children.title: Locking up criminals for longer periods of time has proven one of America's most effective anticrime strategies
children.teaser: Students evaluate arguments and synthesize what they have learned.

children.title: This is about more than safeguarding fair play – it’s about saving lives.
children.teaser: Students establish evidence-based claims as a premises for a logical argument.

children.title: What do I know?
children.teaser: For students, writing is a key means of asserting and defending claims, showing what they know about a subject, and conveying what they have experienced, imagined, thought, and felt.
